for a discussion of the bitter waters; Robert Bartlett also mentions this ordeal in Trial by Fire and Water: The Medieval Judicial Ordeal

The motif of the bitter waters is found in The Trial of Mary and Joseph, a play in the cycle known as the N-Town Play (c. 1460–80). It is the Virgin Mary and Joseph, no less, who are accused of unchastity before the magistrate and the Episcopus. The Bishop decrees that Joseph and Mary must drink a potion—“þe drynge of vengeawns”—and ritually circle the altar. If the accused “be gylty, sum maculacion/Pleyn in his face xal shewe it owth
